messageBody:
Re: method dependency

    > In my class, I have methods A(),B(), C(), where A() must
    > be called before B(), B() before C(). I have individual
    > test cases for each method. In order to run the tests in
    > the specified order, I must arrange the actual methods in
    > the appropriate order. I know this is not a good thing,
    > so how do I avoid it? I really hate to lump them into one
    > testcase.
    >
    > Thanks,
    >
    >
    > Scott

This could be a place for non-JUnit assertions in your code. [I subscribe to the Heresy that XP can be enhanced by design-by-contract, using assertions in addition to unit testing.]

boolean aWasCalled = false;
boolean bWasCalled = false;
boolean cWasCalled = false;

void a()
{
   Assert.isFalse( bWasCalled );
   Assert.isFalse( cWasCalled );
   aWasCalled = true;
   ....
}

void b()
{
   Assert.isTrue( aWasCalled );
   Assert.isFalse( cWasCalled );
   bWasCalled = true;
   ....
}

void c()
{
   Assert.isTrue( aWasCalled );
   Assert.isTrue( bWasCalled );
   ....
}

Now your code communicates that a() must be called before b(), which must be called before c(). This also tests the unit tests, in that your non-JUnit Assert class methods should throw an unchecked exception if b() is called before a(), or c() is called before b() and a().

While people are calling this a 'code smell', does the following smell?
     a() means "open file"
     b() means "write to file"
 and c() means "close file".

However, since the three methods apparently work together, they probably should be tested together.
